ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the behavioral and neural underpinnings of adolescent behavioral patterns.
I gained a better understanding of neuro and the adolescent brain. I thought Prof. Casey taught well.
This course was so fascinating from beginning to end. You learn a lot about the functions of the adolescent brain and also how we can approach them in a way that is conducive to their function.

We learned about different models and trends of adolescent brain development, and we read many papers that supported those models and trends. Specifically, we learned about teen fear learning and risk taking behaviors, sensitivity to rewards and peers, how the brain is either adaptive or maladaptive. We also became familiar with some important brain regions and their functions/development during adolescence. Finally, we connected these studies to the justice system and legal implications for adolescent brain development.
Learned a lot about the neuroscience & psychology of adolescents, children, etc.
I learned so much about the human brain, the adolescent brain, the development of a person overtime, a little on neuro-divergent brains, and so much more.
I learned about adolescent behavior and brain development. I also learned neuroscience experimental methods in clinical and basic research.

I learned a lot about the adolescent brain for sure. I wasn't very excited about this course at first because i felt like the adolescent brain is such a specific time frame, and not an overwhelmingly exciting one, to be studying. But it turned out to be my favorite class. I learned a lot about circuitry, and how to read scientific papers in a way that made sense to me. I learned how to summarize and synthesize scientific papers. I learned how to work with my classmates really well during the debate. I think I gained a lot from this class.

learned how to view studies in an adaptive or maladaptive way; critical thinking; really changed the way I view the adolescent brain and how we learn to take in information from our environment as we grow up
I learned how to read fMRI images and think about connections between neuroscience topics in terms of the adolescent brain.
This was an amazing course in learning how the adolescent (and adult) brain develops and how differences in behavior can be explained
This course provided a really good understanding of  how certain brain systems develop during the adolescent period as well as how this ties into adolescent behavior.
I learned about the adaptive and maladaptive behaviors of the adolescent brain.
I learned about the adolescent brain.
details about adolescent brain
I learned about adolescent development
Basic circuitry and behavior in adolescent development.
Understanding of the adolescent brain and how it can be both adaptive and maladaptive
I learned about the most up to date understandings of the adolescent brain from behavioral, neuroscientific, and legal perspectives.
I learned about the development of the adolescent brain, specifically certain specific traits.
I learned a significant amount about adolescent development. Prof. Casey is an expert in the field, and it was a great to be able to learn from her extensive knowledge about the adolescent brain.
I learned so much about the adolescent brain and how adolescents are affected by peers, rewards, fear, and risks.
I felt like I was able to learn a lot about neuroscience in a more in-depth and practical way than I had been able to get in the Human Brain or any of my Psych classes.

I learned how to combat common myths about the teenage brain with evidence that shows how the adolescent brain is both maladaptive and adaptive. I learned policy and legal implications for the research that was discussed.
An in depth understanding of how the brain develops in varying environments/contexts, neuroscience findings specific to the adolescent brain, and how neuroscience informs social policy
I gained insight into how the adolescent brain differs in development, processing, and responses in comparison to adults and children.
I developed knowledge about how adolescent brain development is understood, the potential theories and models surrounding it, and some recent research about adolescent developmental patterns.
how to read a psychology paper. how to understand different developmental pathways. how to synthesize information and present it in a clear, concise way.
I learned the distinction between different adolescent brain models, concepts, and cognitive pathways.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Casey is thoughtful, thorough, and a passionate lecturer. The pace of the material is definitely manageable, and the assignments are engaging!

Prof. Casey is great and a strength is how wonderful and nice she is. She really cares about her students and you can tell. The one big weakness for me was the exam structure. We have three exams they are 20%, 20% and 25% of our grade. Each exam is 10 multiple choice questions and 10 true/false AND THAT IS IT. So 65% of your grade is made up by 65 multiple choice or t/f questions. I have terrible test anxiety and often show case what I have learned through my writing. Even on an exam if I have an opportunity to write short answers and essay questions they are far stronger. I felt like I was not given the opportunity to showcase what I know or how I learn because of the assessment style in the class, it was really hard for me to do even remotely well on the exams. Prof. Casey would also intentionally trick you on the wording of the questions, and have the questions be a bit unclear.
Dr. BJ Casey is amazing. The course was formatted wonderfully and the topics were super engaging. Zero complaints.

Strengths 
- super interesting material, easy to understand and also very applicable to many fields of studies / life in general 
- pretty low workload
- amazing, very caring professor 


Weaknesses
- the grading system caused a lot of stress because it put a lot of pressure on the exams (each exam question was worth 1% of your grade, and you could only get 5 points off in the whole semester to get an A, etc) ... unforgiving

Strengths of the class was organization, supplemental readings were directly related to the course work, lectures were engaging. Weaknesses include being a 9am. My brain was simply not awake sometimes which just made me retain so much less - I wish the class was recorded so that I could rewatch things when my brain wandered ( I also have attention difficulties sometimes ).
The professor is amazing!!

I think the professor and TF were the biggest strengths. Professor Casey was caring, compassionate, and excited to be there everyday. I may never have a better professor than her. Another strength was the wide variety of assignments to accommodate everyone, no matter their personal strengths. There were small essays, a drawing, a debate, and exams. Everyone is good at different things and I felt like this was a really fair spread of assignments. A weakness is definitely the grading scheme. I feel like a 90 should be an A- not a B+, that is pretty standard, so it is unfortunate that the grading system for this class is skewed a bit. It was also unfortunate how the exams were only 20 questions, so if you miss even just 2, you are in the B's.
strengths: clear course material on slides; know what is expected of you in the class; exam review sessions + review of answers following exam

While the material for the course was very interesting and you gain a lot of relevant insight about the adolescent brain, the structure of the course made it difficult to do well which made the course unnecessarily stressful. Because each point that was deducted over the course of the semester was equivalent to one percent of your grade, this put a lot of pressure on us throughout the course and made the learning experience less enjoyable.
I loved this course. The only slight change I would make is the grading scheme. I feel as if the threshold for A, A-, and B+ are a little too high
I loved the course! It was well taught and well structured. I just wish the exams were short answer. I missed a lot of points that I know I could have gotten had I been able to explain myself.
this class was very well organized.

The strengths of this course lie in how Professor Casey continuously drove home the important points of the course and the implications for certain findings were always explained during lecture. I don't find that this course had any weaknesses, it is really a fantastic class.

Strengths of the course were the engaging material covered, the insightful discussions within the class, and the manageable assigned readings. Some weaknesses of the course were the lack of opportunities to engage with my peers and have engaging discussions.
The grading was tough in that each question was 1% off of your grade, and you needed a 95% to get an A.

Strengths: course lectures were very informative and I appreciated that in the beginning of each lecture there was a mini review of last class

Weaknesses: Some projects like the concept map and debate were emphasized but I wished they were worth more of our grade for the amount of effort we put into them. Exams are only multiple choice which could be a strength for some but very much not built for people who are bad test takers.
-I think the grade cut offs are a bit harsh, but other than that wonderful and fun course
Interactive and engaging
This course is very cool and I think the setup with the exams and debates and concept maps could be a strength for some people and a weakness for others.

Strengths: engaging lecture, good number of assignments
Weaknesses: questions on tests unnecessarily tricky, wish that they were just short answer so that students could demonstrate knowledge.

I appreciated having the reading responses as they encouraged me more actively engage with the material and prepared me well for class. I thought that the exam format (and generally workload) was very kind and Professor Casey was very considerate of our other coursework.

This course is strong in that the material is highly interesting. There is a correct balance of readings, assessments, and tests. However, the grading scale of the course (95 = A), was overly harsh given the circumstances of this year. Compared to the test grades from the year online, our class' average was close to the lowest grade from last year. As a result, the Professor had to give points back on the tests that skewed the grades. I would have preferred if the grading scale was normal and no points back on the tests.

I thought that the course sometimes missed some depth that I was hoping for. We learned a lot about the adolescent brain, but sometimes the content missed going a bit deeper into why it is important, what we can do with that information, or what the implications of that are. 

I also thought the exam structure was a weakness of the course. Having only 20 question exams that were all multiple choice and true or false took away any opportunity for students to fully demonstrate what they had learned from the course. I would study several days for the exam and most of the content I studied would not show up on the exam. I would have preferred more questions especially for the final exam and some free response questions! The debate was a little awkward with so many people on each team -- it was entertaining but I don't think it actually deepened my knowledge much. 

Prof. Casey is great and she does try her best to make the course engaging and fun! The content was interesting and I really liked that we were finished with everything by the start of reading week -- took a lot of pressure off so that I could focus on other courses that had deadlines and finals during reading and finals week.

The course has no weaknesses. I like how we can do reading responses for the topics that we prefer rather than having weekly assignments. Another strength is that the review session before each exam was really helpful.

I thought the more creative and different assignments like the concept map and the debate actually helped me engage with the material the most out of any of the assignments. And the lectures were also very informative and relatively easy to follow.

This course is fun, engaging, and has a wide variety of assignments that can fit a range of learning styles. Professor Casey is the sweetest and is very knowledgeable about everything in the course. Her anecdotes combined with relevant research make this class worthwhile.

The lectures were very clear and I found that I retained information more easily because of we would usually do a brief review of last week's lecture before the current one. The reading responses were a great way to engage with the course material, and because we had options of topics, they were usually pretty interesting to write. I thought the debate was quite fun and a low stakes way to synthesize the information we've learned from the semester. I thought the exams were both a weakness and a strength. The questions were straightforward and I didn't have a hard time figuring out how to study for them. However, because there are so few questions in the exams, there is very little room for error. It would have been nice to have slightly longer exams or maybe exams where there is some possibility for partial credit.

This course was very interesting. I would have been improved if the class was a little smaller, there was a lot of content that could have been expanded upon. I really liked the readings and Dr. Casey was a very thoughtful and engaging lecturer.

Strengths - well organized, manageable workload, engaging lectures
Weaknesses - the debate was a somewhat confusing assignment, and stressful without any real feedback given or real knowledge gained by the process
lectures went by so fast but in order to get all the info it needed to happen that way. liked the idea of the debate. the cut from 10 reading responses to 5 was very helpful.

Strength- the material was engaging and BJ Casey is an amazing lecturer 
Weakness- the reading responses was more work than the points they were worth

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would strongly recommend this course to another student if you are interested in psychology, cognitive science, neuroscience, law, medicine, or culture! Truly, such a broad-reaching course.
ONLY IF YOU ARE GOOD AT MULTIPLE CHOICE!!! or you can credit/d
Absolutely. One of the courses I recommend you take before graduating from Yale.

Yes! Not sure how it would be with a different professor (hopefully a better grading system that doesn't put so much pressure on the exams to get a perfect score?), but either way, the material is super interesting, and I loved taking the class!! I actually feel like I've walked away with a lot of information that will stick with me + I won't just forget it all after the final
Yes! I don't know if the course will exist now that Prof. Casey is leaving, but its super interesting and you learn a lot about your own development and way of thinking about things.
ABSOLUTELY! Probably one of my favorite courses at yale so far. Professor Casey is amazing and the material is so interesting and so well taught.
I would recommend this course to others especially those who are majoring in psychology or neuroscience.
I would recommend this very much so. I think this is a fantastic course for everyone who has taken The Human Brain, even if you aren't a neuro or psych major. It was a great experience.
yes yes yes!! really impactful to view brain development from a new lens
If you are interested in the material, this class is worth it. However, if the structure does not change, there might be other courses that would provide for a less stressful experience.
Yes!!! Loved this course so much.
Absolutely it was one of the best classes I took

While a bit disorganized at times, if you're even somewhat interested in the material, take it!! Professor Casey does an excellent job of driving home important findings, the assignments and tests are super fair and the class as a whole is set up for you to do really well!!
Yes, especially if you are a Neuroscience major or just have an interest in the adolescent brain.
Yea, it's a great course, and Dr. Casey is fantastic, but she said she will not be teaching it again in the future, so I can't recommend this specific form of the course to future students.
Absolutely
Yes! Fascinating topic
I would recommend this course to another student if it helps them fill requirements.
If youre a psychology major then yes
Yes, but only if you're already interested in the subject.
I would recommend this course to students interested in the basics of adolescent development but caution about the skewed grading scale.
It's a good depth requirement course for Cog Sci that is not too stressful but still allows you to learn!

Yes!!!! This courses is amazing! Youll learn a lot of interesting things about the teenage brain without feeling bored. The course is low workload as well and allows you enough time to engage with the material.
I think this course is great for anyone interested in neuroscience. It teaches about a lot of things that are very important to consider in the neuroscience field.
Yes, please take this course! It is super engaging, interesting, and you get lots of clear feedback about your progress throughout the class. I loved coming to class even though it was at 9am.
Yes! If you're into psychology and neuroscience, this is a course that covers very interesting topics. It's a fun and low pressure way to learn a lot of developmental neuroscience.
Absolutely, this course provided fascinating insight into how we as adolescents view the world and why it happens to be that way.

I would recommend this course to any student, I think it is accessible to non neuroscience/psych majors, but is also important information for people in these majors. It gives good insight into some of the disagreements and ongoing study into aspects of psychology, while also being a manageable and interesting course.
If you are interested in learning more about adolescence, yes. And if you are engaged with more of the science side of psychology.
yes!!
Yes! Engaging and interesting and informative
